key_work.brief_description: In Picnic at Hanging Rock (2018), Mrs Hester Appleyard (Natalie Dormer) appears exactly as she wishes to be seen: a proper lady, overseeing the social and intellectual development of her students. But even here, the story’s ominous undertones are foreshadowed. While Appleyard’s structured dresses hint at the strictness she exerts over her image, she’s also consistently dressed in darker colours than the other women. If this was an attempt to fade into the background as an unremarkable widow, it fails. If the girls’ white picnic dresses are ethereal, the headmistress’ silhouette and colour scheme is foreboding, giving a glimpse into the shadowy spectre of her past.

key_work.title: Picnic at Hanging Rock (2018) picnic costumes
key_work.brief_description: Before their Valentine’s Day journey to Mt Diogenes, the students look pristine in these white dresses – picture-perfect young women ready to enter society. When the girls go missing, these once-innocent dresses take on an ethereal, intangible quality. As the students shed their gloves and boots, delving deeper into Mt Diogenes, they seem to disappear into the landscape while gaining a sense of freedom, wildness and mysterious purpose. “We’re here at last. We’ve escaped,” Miranda (Lily Sullivan) tells Ms McCraw (Anna McGahan) when they arrive. Through flashbacks and dream sequences, our perspective on their disappearance changes – is it a tragedy or an escape?

end.title: The Lord of the rings: the fellowship of the ring
end.creator_credit: Peter Jackson, Fran Walsh, Tim Sanders, New Line Cinema and Wingnut Films
end.brief_description: Iconic adaptation of J R R Tolkien’s fantasy epic, “The Lord of the rings: the fellowship of the rings” is the first instalment of the “Rings” trilogy. Director Peter Jackson (Heavenly creatures, The Frighteners, Meet the Feebles) went to incredible lengths to re-create Tolkien’s fantastical vision to the screen, by building extensive realistic sets in his native New Zealand, and by employing a slew of gifted special effects artists. In short, Frodo Baggins, a kind-hearted and earnest hobbit, is entrusted with the gallant mission to return a powerful ring from whence it came - Mount Doom, the only place where it can be destroyed. Failure to do so will result in the destruction of the earth, as the powerful ring is capable of unleashing inestimable evil. Guided by Gandalf, a powerful wizard, Frodo is accompanied on his treacherous journey by three hobbit friends, a dwarf, an elf and several humans. This heroic quest invokes all the necessary thrills of an adventure picture, whilst satiating the exacting standards of an audience inured to CGI wizardry, and gratifying legions of zealous Tolkien fans. With ambitious battle scenes and stupendous set pieces, this grand and masterful cinematic spectacle kept most viewers utterly enthralled, whilst earning Jackson almost universal praise for capturing Tolkien’s mythopoeic narrative and elegiac tone.

end.brief_description: Director/writer Kevin Smith’s (Clerks, Mallrats, Chasing Amy) comedic interpretation of the Catholic religion caused controversy before its release and continues to do so today, despite Smith’s claim that “Dogma” is about rediscovering your faith in God and shouldn’t be taken too seriously.
